Galata Tower

[TAB]The Galata Tower (Galata Kulesi in Turkish), called Christea Turris (the Tower of Christ in Latin) by the Genoese, is a medieval stone tower in the Galata district of Istanbul, Turkey, just to the north of the Golden Horn. One of the city's most striking landmarks, it is a high, cone-capped cylinder that dominates the skyline and affords a panoramic vista of Old Istanbul and its environment.[PARAGRAPH:2]The tower was built as Christea Turris (Tower of Christ) in 1348 during an expansion of the Genoese colony in Constantinople. It was the apex of the fortifications surrounding the Genoese citadel of Galata. The current tower should not be confused with the old Tower of Galata, an original Byzantine tower named Megalos Pyrgos (English: Great Tower) which controlled the northern end of the massive sea chain that closed the entrance to the Golden Horn. That tower was on a different site and was largely destroyed in 1203, during the Fourth Crusade of 1202 - 1204.
[ICON_BULLET]Increases spread chance of Trading Companies in all your cities
Kizil Kule

[TAB]The Kizil Kule (Red Tower) is a historical tower in the Turkish city of Alanya. The building is considered to be the symbol of the city, and is even used on the city's flag.[PARAGRAPH:2]Construction of the building began in the early reign of the Anatolian Seljuq Sultan Ala ad-Din Kay Qubadh I and was completed in 1226. The sultan brought the accomplished architect Ebu Ali Reha from Aleppo, Syria to Alanya to complete the building. The octagonal red brick tower protects the Tersane (shipyard) which dates from 1221.[PARAGRAPH:2]The name derives from the more red color brick he used in its construction. The building itself is 33 m high and 12.5 m wide. It remains one of the finest examples of medieval military architecture, and is the best preserved Seljuk building in the city. Like many buildings in the city, the Tower flies a Turkish Flag from its crenelations.
[ICON_BULLET]+2[ICON_COMMERCE] from [LINK=literal]Harbor[\LINK] in all cities[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]+25% Defense in All Coastal Cities
Gediminas' Tower

[TAB]The Vilnius Castle Complex is a group of cultural and historic structures on the left bank of the Neris River, near its confluence with the Vilnia River. The buildings, which evolved between the 10th and 18th centuries, were one of Lithuania's major defensive structures. One part of the castle complex, which was built on a hilltop, is known as the Upper Castle, while Gediminas' Tower is the only remaining part of the Upper Castle.[PARAGRAPH:2]The first fortifications were built of wood, and since about the 13th century the hilltop has been surrounded by stone walls with towers. During the rule of Gediminas, Vilnius was designated as the capital city; in 1323, the castle was improved and expanded. The first brick castle was completed in 1409 by Grand Duke Vytautas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Pagan Lithuania waged war with the Christian Orders for more than two centuries. The Orders were seeking to conquer Lithuania, stating that their motivation was the conversion of pagan Lithuanians to Catholicism. As Vilnius evolved into one of the most important cities in the state, it became a primary military target. The Castle Complex was attacked by the Teutonic Order in 1365, 1375, 1377, 1383, 1390, 1392, 1394 and 1402, but was never completely taken.[PARAGRAPH:2]After a major fire in 1419, Vytautas initiated a reconstruction of the Upper Castle, along with the fortification of other buildings in the complex (in Gothic style), and it served an important role in the following centuries.[PARAGRAPH:2]After the 16th century, the Upper Castle was not maintained, and it suffered from neglect. It was used as a fortress for the last time during the invasion of the Russians in 1655, when for the first time in Lithuanian history, a foreign army captured the entire complex. Even though the Polish-Lithuanian army managed to recapture Vilnius and the castles six years later, the Upper Castle stood abandoned and was not reconstructed afterwards.[PARAGRAPH:2]Today, the remaining Gediminas' Tower is a major state and historic symbol of the city of Vilnius and of the nation itself. It is depicted on the national currency, the litas, and is mentioned in numerous Lithuanian patriotic poems and folk songs. The Flag of Lithuania was re-hoisted atop the tower on October 7, 1988, during the independence movement that was finalized by the Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania on March 11, 1990. A reconstruction of the Royal Palace of Lithuania was completed in 2009, and is located near the base of the hill upon which Gediminas' Tower stands.
[ICON_BULLET]Restores some of the city defenses on Combat Victory
Torre del Oro

[TAB]The Torre del Oro (English: "Gold Tower") is a dodecagonal military watchtower in Seville, southern Spain, built by the Almohad dynasty in order to control access to Seville via the Guadalquivir river.[PARAGRAPH:2]Constructed in the first third of the 13th century, the tower served as a prison during the Middle Ages and as a secure enclosure for the protection of precious metals periodically brought by the fleet of the Indies, another possible origin for the tower's name.[PARAGRAPH:2]It is one of two anchor points for a large chain that would have been able to block the river. The other anchor-point has since been demolished or disappeared, possibly from collapsing during the 1755 Lisbon Earthquake. The chain was used in the city's defense against the Castilian fleet under Ramon de Bonifaz in 1248 Reconquista. Bonifaz broke the river defenses and isolated Seville from Triana. The besieged Muslim city soon surrendered to the Christian forces.
[ICON_BULLET]Chance for a minor Golden Age on Colony completion
The Duomo

[TAB]The Basilica di Santa Maria del Fiore (English: Basilica of Saint Mary of the Flower) is the main church of Florence, Italy. The Duomo, as it is ordinarily called, was begun in 1296 in the Gothic style to the design of Arnolfo di Cambio and completed structurally in 1436 with the dome engineered by Filippo Brunelleschi. The exterior of the basilica is faced with polychrome marble panels in various shades of green and pink bordered by white and has an elaborate 19th century Gothic Revival facade by Emilio De Fabris.[PARAGRAPH:2]The cathedral complex, located in Piazza del Duomo, includes the Baptistery and Giotto's Campanile. The three buildings are part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site covering the historic centre of Florence and are a major attraction to tourists visiting the region of Tuscany. The basilica is one of Italy's largest churches, and until development of new structural materials in the modern era, the dome was the largest in the world. It remains the largest brick dome ever constructed.
[ICON_BULLET]Fewer Temples are required for building Cathedrals (-1 per Cathedral)
Mont Saint-Michel

[TAB]Mont Saint-Michel is a rocky tidal island and a commune in Normandy, France. It is located approximately one kilometre off the country's north-western coast, at the mouth of the Couesnon River near Avranches. The population of the island is 41, as of 2006. The island has been a strategic point holding fortifications since ancient times, and since the 8th century AD it became the seat of the Saint-Michel monastery, from which it draws the name. The Mont-Saint-Michel and its bay are part of the UNESCO list of World Heritage Sites. More than 3,000,000 people visit it each year.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mont Saint-Michel was used in the 6th and 7th centuries as an Armorican stronghold of Romano-Breton culture and power, until it was ransacked by the Franks, thus ending the trans-channel culture that had stood since the departure of the Romans in AD 460. Before the construction of the first monastic establishment in the 8th century, the island was called "monte tombe". According to legend, the Archangel Michael appeared to St. Aubert, bishop of Avranches, in 708 and instructed him to build a church on the rocky islet. Aubert repeatedly ignored the angel's instruction, until Michael burned a hole in the bishop's skull with his finger.
[ICON_BULLET]Building [LINK=literal]Walls[\LINK] and [LINK=literal]Castle[\LINK] increases Faith in your civilization
Boyana Church

[TAB]The Boyana Church is a medieval Bulgarian Orthodox church situated on the outskirts of Sofia. In 1979, the building was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List. The east wing of the two-storey church was originally constructed in the late 10th or early 11th century, then the central wing was added in the 13th century under the Second Bulgarian Empire, the whole building being finished with a further expansion to the west in the middle of the 19th century. A total of 89 scenes with 240 human images are depicted on the walls of the church.[PARAGRAPH:2]Besides the first layer of 11th-12th-century frescoes, of which only fragments are preserved, and the famous second layer of murals from 1259, the church also has a smaller number of later frescoes from the 14th and 16th-17th centuries, as well as from 1882. The church owes its world fame mainly to its frescoes from 1259. They form a second layer over the paintings from earlier centuries and represent one of the most complete and well-preserved monuments of medieval art in the Balkans.[PARAGRAPH:2]Eighteen scenes in the narthex depict the life of Saint Nicholas. The painter here drew certain aspects of contemporary lifestyle. In The Miracle at Sea, the ship and the sailors' hats recall the Venetian fleet. The portraits of the patrons of the church - Sebastocrator Kaloyan and his wife Dessislava, as well as those of Bulgarian tsar Constantine Tikh and Tsaritsa Irina, are thought to be among the most impressive and lifelike frescoes in the church, and are located on the north wall of the church.
[ICON_BULLET]Doubles faith points from the "Write great work of Theology" action of Great Theologians
Samogitian Alkas

[TAB]The Samogitian Alkas is a pagan sanctuary located at the hills near Sventoji (in the vicinity of Palanga). It's origin is a 14th century astronomical observatory site, which was installed on the top of Mount Birute. The site was restored in 1988.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the restoration of the pagan sanctuary, wooden columns carved by folk artists were put up in the Samogitian Sanctuary and each of the columns symbolizes the names of mythological gods and goddesses of the Balts: Perkunas (Thunder), Ausrine (Morning star the Venus), Zemyna (Goddess of Earth Vitality), Austeja (Goddess of Bees), Ondenis (Water God), Patrimpas (God of plants and Spring), Patulas (Unger earth God), Velnias (God of Dead Souls), Leda (Mother of Gods and heavenly bodies), Saule (the Sun) and Menulis (the Moon). When the sun goes down to the sea, these columns help to determine pagan calendar holidays.[PARAGRAPH:2]Now pagan feasts connected to the holidays are celebrated here, while pagan ceremonies and rituals in the honour of amber are still organised at the site.
[ICON_BULLET]+2[ICON_RESEARCH] from [LINK=literal]Pagan Shrine[\LINK] in all cities
Borgund Stave Church

[TAB]Borgund Stave Church is a stave church located in Borgund, Norway. It is classified as a triple nave stave church of the so-called Sogn-type. This is also the best preserved of Norway's 28 extant stave churches.[PARAGRAPH:2]Borgund was built sometime between 1180 and 1250 CE with later additions and restorations. Its walls are formed by vertical wooden boards, or staves, hence the name "stave church". The four corner posts were connected to one another by ground sills, resting on a stone foundation. The rest of the staves then rise from the ground sills, each stave notched and grooved along the sides so that they lock into one another, forming a sturdy wall.
The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Borgund Stave Church[COLOR_REVERT] allows the player to build religious buildings at a reduced cost.
[ICON_BULLET]Production cost of Religious buildings is reduced by 40% in all cities
Blue Mosque

[TAB]The Sultan Ahmed Mosque is a historical mosque in Istanbul, the largest city in Turkey and the capital of the Ottoman Empire from 1453 to 1923. The mosque is popularly known as the Blue Mosque: Hand-painted blue tiles adorn the mosque's interior walls, and at night the mosque is bathed in blue as lights frame the mosque's five main domes, six minarets and eight secondary domes. It was built between 1609 and 1616, during the rule of Ahmed I. Like many other mosques, it also comprises a tomb of the founder, a madrasah and a hospice.[PARAGRAPH:2]The design of the Sultan Ahmed Mosque is the culmination of two centuries of both Ottoman mosque and Byzantine church development. It incorporates some Byzantine elements of the neighboring Hagia Sophia with traditional Islamic architecture and is considered to be the last great mosque of the classical period. The architect has ably synthesized the ideas of his master Mimar Sinan, aiming for overwhelming size, majesty and splendour.[PARAGRAPH:2]At its lower levels and at every pier, the interior of the mosque is lined with more than 20,000 handmade ceramic tiles, made at Iznik (the ancient Nicaea) in more than fifty different tulip designs. At gallery level their design becomes flamboyant with representations of flowers, fruit and cypresses, while there are more than 200 stained glass windows in the mosque. The upper levels of the interior are dominated by blue paint.
[ICON_BULLET]-20% production cost in all cities for buildings present in the capital city
Selimiye Mosque

[TAB]The Selimiye Mosque (Turkish: Selimiye Camii) is an Ottoman imperial mosque, which is located in the city of Edirne, Turkey. The mosque was commissioned by Sultan Selim II, and was built by architect Mimar Sinan between 1569 and 1575. It was considered by Sinan to be his masterpiece and is one of the highest achievements of Islamic architecture.[PARAGRAPH:2]Selimiye Mosque was built at the peak of Ottoman military and cultural power. As the empire started to grow, the emperor had found an immediate urge to centralize the city. Sinan was asked to help to construct the Selimiye Mosque, making the mosque distinctive and served the purpose of centralizing the city. In this mosque he employed an octagonal supporting system that is created through eight pillars incised in a square shell of walls. The four semi domes at the corners of the square behind the arches that spring from the pillars, are intermediary sections between the huge encompassing dome (31.25 metres diameter with spherical profile) and the walls. The beauty resulting from the conformity of geometric shapes engulfed in each other was the culmination of Sinan's lifelong search for a unified interior space.[PARAGRAPH:2]The interior of the mosque received great recognitions from its clean, spare lines in the structure itself. With the monumental exteriors proclaiming the wealth and power of the Ottoman Empire, the plain symmetrical interiors reminded the sultans should always provide a humble and faithful heart in order to connect and communicate with God. To enter, it was to forget the power, determination, wealth and technical mastery of the Ottoman Empire. Lights were seeped through multitude of tiny windows, and the interchanging of the weak light and dark was interpreted as the insignificance of humanity. The Selimiye did not only amaze the public with the extravagant symmetrical exterior, it had also astonished the people with the plain symmetrical interior for it had summarized all Ottoman architectural thinking in one simple pure form.
[ICON_BULLET]+100% Experience Points for new units during Golden Ages (in all cities)
Al-Azhar University

[TAB]Al-Azhar University ("the (honorable) Azhar University") is a university in Cairo, Egypt. Associated with Al-Azhar Mosque in Islamic Cairo, it is Egypt's oldest degree-granting university and is renowned as "Sunni Islam's most prestigious university".[PARAGRAPH:2]Founded in 970 or 972 as a centre of Islamic learning, it is one of the relics of the Isma'ili Shia Fatimid dynasty era of Egypt. Its students studied the Qur'an and Islamic law in detail, along with logic, grammar, rhetoric, and how to calculate the phases of the moon. It was one of the first universities in the world, and the only one in the Arabic world to survive as a modern university including secular subjects in the curriculum. Today it is the chief centre of Arabic literature and Islamic learning in the world.[PARAGRAPH:2]Studies began at Al-Azhar in the month of Ramadan, 975. The Jami'ah (Madrasa) had faculties in Islamic law and jurisprudence, Arabic grammar, Islamic astronomy, Islamic philosophy, and logic. The Fatimids gave attention to the philosophical studies at the time when rulers in other countries declared those who were engaged in philosophical pursuits as apostates and heretics. The Greek thought found a warm reception with the Fatimids who expanded the boundaries of such studies. They paid much attention to philosophy and gave support to everyone who was known for being engaged in the study of any branch of philosophy. The Fatimid Caliph invited many scholars from nearby countries and paid much attention to college books on various branches of knowledge and in gathering the finest writing on various subjects and this in order to encourage scholars and to uphold the cause of knowledge. Most of these books were destroyed by Saladin though, when he converted Al-Azhar to a Shafi'ite Sunni center of learning.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1961 additional non-religious subjects were added to its curriculum: a wide range of secular faculties were added for the first time, such as business, economics, science, pharmacy, medicine, engineering and agriculture. In addition to higher education, Al-Azhar oversees a national network of schools with approximately two million students. As of 1996, over 4000 teaching institutes in Egypt were affiliated with the University.[PARAGRAPH:2]Its library is considered second in importance in Egypt only to the Egyptian National Library and Archives. In May 2005, Al-Azhar launched a project to eventually publish online access to the library's entire rare manuscripts collection, comprising about seven million pages of material.
The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Al-Azhar University[COLOR_REVERT] increases research progress for all religious technologies, effectively reducing the cost required to complete them.
[ICON_BULLET]-50%[ICON_RESEARCH] cost for Religious Technologies
Great Mosque of Kairouan

[TAB]The Great Mosque of Kairouan, also known as the Mosque of Uqba, is a mosque in Tunisia, situated in the UNESCO World Heritage town of Kairouan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Established by the Arab general Uqba ibn Nafi in 670 AD at the founding of the city of Kairouan, the mosque is spread over a surface area of 9,000 square metres and it is one of the oldest places of worship in the Islamic world, as well as a model for all later mosques in the Maghreb. The Great Mosque of Kairouan is one of the most impressive and largest Islamic monuments in North Africa; its perimeter is almost equal to 405 metres (1,328 feet). This space contains a hypostyle prayer hall, a marble-paved courtyard and a square minaret. In addition to its spiritual prestige, the Mosque of Uqba is one of the masterpieces of Islamic architecture, notable among other things for the first Islamic use of the horseshoe arch.[PARAGRAPH:2]Under the Aghlabids (9th century), huge works gave the mosque its present aspect. The fame of the Mosque of Uqba and of the other holy sites at Kairouan helped the city to develop and repopulate increasingly. The university, consisting of scholars who taught in the mosque, was a centre of education both in Islamic thought and in the secular sciences. Its role can be compared to that of the University of Paris in the Middle Ages. With the decline of the city of Kairouan from the mid-11th century (The Banu Hilal tribes so utterly destroyed Kairouan in 1057 that it never regained its former importance and their influx was a major factor in the spread of nomadism in areas where agriculture had previously been dominant), the centre of intellectual thought moved to the University of Ez-Zitouna in Tunis and other major cities in the Maghreb.
Koutoubia Mosque

[TAB]The Koutoubia Mosque or Kutubiyya Mosque is the largest mosque in Marrakesh, Morocco, located in the southwest medina quarter of Marrakesh. The mosque is ornamented with curved windows, a band of ceramic inlay, pointed merlons, and decorative arches; it has a large plaza with gardens, and is floodlit at night. The minaret, 77 metres (253 ft) in height, includes a spire and orbs. It was completed under the reign of the Berber Almohad Caliph Yaqub al-Mansur (1184 to 1199), and has inspired other buildings such as the Giralda of Seville and the Hassan Tower of Rabat.[PARAGRAPH:2]The city of Marrakesh was captured by the Almohads after the death of the Almoravid leader Ali ibn Yusuf in 1147. The Almohads did not want any trace of religious monuments built by the Almoravids, their staunch enemies, as they considered them heretics. Abd-al-Mu'min, who won the territory, was responsible for building the first Koutoubiya mosque on the grounds of the former palace of Ali ibn Yusuf in the southwest quarter of the medina. This first mosque was started between 1147 and 1154 and completed in 1157.[PARAGRAPH:2]A second mosque was built under the Almohad Caliph Yaqub al-Mansur, as it was realized halfway through construction that the initial mosque's mihrab (prayer niche) was misaligned and not oriented towards Mecca. In some opinions the second mosque was already undergoing construction when the first mosque was completed. The second mosque was built identical to the first except for its orientation. The layout, architectural designs, inscriptions, dimensions and materials used for construction were all the same. The minaret plan and design remained the same in both buildings. It was completed by the 1190s, though reported completion dates vary between 1190 and 1199. The first mosque eventually deteriorated. It is apparent that the second mosque was not built as an alternative to the first one, as the two mosques shared the same site for 30 years before the first mosque became derelict. Funnily, while in the first mosque the orientation of the mihrab was 5 degrees out of alignment with respect to the direction towards Mecca, in the second mosque the orientation was 10 degrees off, thus actually further out of alignment with Mecca than the first mosque.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Koutoubia Mosque and tower constitute the oldest and most complete structure of the Almohad period. The mosque was followed by two other structures built on the same pattern, the Tour Hassan in Rabat and the Giralda in Seville, Spain. This structure thus became the forerunner of Moroccan-Andalusian architecture. Non-Muslims are not allowed inside the mosque; however, they are permitted to visit the Tin Mal Mosque, built on the lines of Koutoubia Mosque.[PARAGRAPH:2]The mosque is made of red stone, formerly plastered, and has six rooms in succession, one above the other. It was designed so as to prevent anyone gazing in from the minaret to the harems of the king. Even in the modern day, such restrictions are enforced by blocking Google Earth access to Moroccans.
[ICON_BULLET]+4 stability points with [LINK=literal]Religious Law[\LINK]
St. Catherine's Monastery

[TAB]Built between 548 and 565, Saint Catherine's Monastery is one of the oldest working Christian monasteries in the world. It lies on the Sinai Peninsula, at the mouth of a gorge at the foot of Mount Sinai, near the town of Saint Catherine, Egypt. The monastery is controlled by the autonomous Church of Sinai, part of the wider Eastern Orthodox Church, and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.[PARAGRAPH:2]The site contains the world's oldest continually operating library, possessing many unique books including the Syriac Sinaiticus and, until 1859, the Codex Sinaiticus (a manuscript dating from the 4th Century, at the time the oldest almost completely preserved manuscript of the Bible). The monastery library preserves the second largest collection of early codices and manuscripts in the world, outnumbered only by the Vatican Library. It contains Greek, Arabic, Armenian, Coptic, Hebrew, Georgian, Aramaic and Caucasian Albanian texts.[PARAGRAPH:2]According to tradition, Catherine of Alexandria was a Christian martyr sentenced to death on the breaking wheel. When this failed to kill her, she was beheaded, and angels took her remains to Mount Sinai. Around the year 800, monks from the Sinai Monastery found her remains.[PARAGRAPH:1]Although it is commonly known as Saint Catherine's, the monastery's full official name is the Sacred Monastery of the God-Trodden Mount Sinai. The patronal feast of the monastery is the Feast of the Transfiguration. The monastery has become a favorite site of pilgrimage.
[ICON_BULLET]Provides 2 Holy Relics
Summer Palace

[TAB]A palace is the home of a head of state or other high-ranking public figure. Many palaces are now put to other uses such as parliaments or museums. Heads of State, especially monarchs, usually spend some weeks each year in other palaces that are not their primary residence. Such palaces are often called Winter Palaces or Summer Palaces, depending on the season they are used. A few examples are the Russian Winter Palace in St. Petersburg, the Chinese Summer Palace in Beijing, and the Kucuksu Summer Palace in Istanbul.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un palais est un lieu où réside un chef d'Etat ou un personnage public important. Beaucoup de palais ont aujourd'hui été reconvertis en parlements ou en musées. Les chefs d'Etat, et principalement les monarques, passent généralement quelques semaines par an dans des palais secondaires. Ces palais sont souvent appelés palais d'hiver ou palais d'été, suivant la saison à laquelle ils sont occupés. On peut citer, par exemple, le palais d'hiver de Saint-Pétersbourg en Russie, le palais d'été de Beijing en Chine, et le palais d'été de Küçüksu à Istanbul.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Residenz ist der Wohnsitz eines Staatsoberhaupts oder einer anderen hochrangigen Person des öffentlichen Lebens. Viele Residenzen dienen heute als Parlamentssitze oder Museen. Staatsoberhäupter, insbesondere Monarchen, leben in der Regel einige Wochen im Jahr nicht in ihrem Hauptwohnsitz, sondern (je nach Jahreszeit) in ihren so genannten Winter- oder Sommerresidenzen. Beispiele hierfür sind der russische Winterpalast in St. Petersburg, der chinesische Sommerpalast in Peking und der Kücüksu-Sommerpalast in Istanbul.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un palazzo è la casa di un capo di stato o di un'altra importante figura pubblica. Molti palazzi ora sono adibiti a usi diversi, come parlamenti o musei. I capi di stato, specialmente i monarchi, passano qualche settimana ogni anno in palazzi che non sono la loro residenza primaria. Solitamente sono chiamati palazzo d'inverno o d'estate, a seconda della stagione in cui vengono usati. Un esempio sono il Palazzo d'Inverno a San Pietroburgo, il Palazzo d'Estate a Pechino e il Palazzo d'Estate Kucuksu a Istanbul.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un palacio es el hogar del jefe de estado o de otro personaje público de alto rango. Hoy en día, muchos palacios se usan para cosas diferentes, por ejemplo, como sedes del Parlamento o museos. Los cabezas de estado, especialmente los monarcas, solían pasar algunas semanas del año fuera de su residencia habitual, en otros palacios. Dichos edificios solían recibir el nombre de palacios de invierno o de verano, en función de la estación en la que fueran utilizados. Algunos ejemplos son el Palacio de Invierno ruso de San Petersburgo, el Palacio de Verano chino de Pekín, y el Palacio de Kucuksu, de verano, en Estambul.

TEXT.English: National University

[TAB]The University of Oxford, England, is the oldest university in the English-speaking world. It is also one of the most prestigious. The exact date of the university's founding is unknown, but scholars believe it was some time around 1100 AD.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oxford is made up of 39 colleges and seven "permanent private halls" (which are religious organizations). Each is housed in a separate building usually built in a square around a quadrangle. The colleges generally consist of a great hall, a chapel, a library, a bar, several common rooms, classrooms, and lodging for around 300 students. Built in the 1250s, Balliol, Merton, and University Colleges are among the oldest.[PARAGRAPH:2]For most of its existence, Oxford has been one of the world's great universities, and it remains so to this day. Many famous people have passed through its halls, including four English and eight foreign kings, over 50 presidents and prime ministers (including US President William Clinton), 47 Nobel Prize winners, and one pope.
TEXT.French: [TAB]L'université d'Oxford en Angleterre est la plus vieille université du monde anglophone. Elle est aussi l'une des plus prestigieuses. La date exacte de sa fondation est inconnue mais des spécialistes estiment qu'elle a été construite vers 1100 ap. J.-C.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oxford compte 39 collèges et 7 "permanent private halls" (qui sont des fondations religieuses). Chacun occupe un bâtiment différent construit généralement sur le modèle d'un carré entourant une cour carrée. Les collèges consistent généralement en une grande salle, une chapelle, une bibliothèque, une cafétéria, plusieurs salles de détente, des salles de cours et des logements pour environ 300 étudiants. Construits dans les années 1250, les collèges Balliol, Merton et University font partie des plus anciens.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oxford a pratiquement toujours été l'une des plus grandes universités du monde et elle le reste aujourd'hui encore. De nombreux personnages célèbres y ont étudié, notamment 4 rois britanniques et 8 étrangers, plus de 50 présidents et premiers ministres (y compris l'ancien président américain Bill Clinton), 47 détenteurs d'un prix Nobel et un pape.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Universität im englischen Oxford ist die älteste Universität der englischsprachigen Welt. Der genaue Zeitpunkt ihrer Gründung ist unbekannt. Wissenschaftler gehen davon aus, dass sie bereits um 1100 nach Christus gegründet wurde.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oxford besteht aus 39 Colleges und sieben so genannten "Permanent Private Halls" religiöser Organisationen. Die Colleges bestehen im Allgemeinen aus einer großen Halle, einer Kapelle, einer Bibliothek, einer Mensa, einigen Gemeinschaftsräumen, Klassenräumen sowie Unterkünften für etwa 300 Studenten. Die ältesten Colleges (Balliol, Merton und das University College) wurden um 1250 gebaut.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oxford gehörte seit ihrer Gründung stets zu den größten Universitäten der Welt. Viele berühmte Persönlichkeiten haben hier studiert; unter anderem vier britische und acht ausländische Könige, über 50 Präsidenten und Premierminister (z. B. Bill Clinton), 47 Nobelpreisträger und ein Papst.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'università di Oxford in Inghilterra, è la più antica università del mondo di lingua Inglese, oltre a essere una delle più prestigiose. La data esatta della fondazione dell'università è sconosciuta, ma gli studiosi credono sia attorno al 1100 d. C.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oxford è composta da 39 college e sette e sette "case degli studenti permanenti" (che sono organizzazioni religiose); ogni facoltà si trova in edifici differenti in piazze vicino a una corte quadrangolare. I college sono in genere formati da una grande sala, una cappella, una libreria, un bar, diverse stanze comuni, classi e alloggi per circa 300 studenti. Costruiti nel 1250, i college Balliol, Merton e University sono tra i più antichi.[PARAGRAPH:2]Per la maggior parte della sua esistenza, Oxford è stata una della più grandi università del mondo e lo è anche tutt'oggi: molti personaggi famosi sono passati da qui, compresi quattro re Inglesi e otto stranieri, più di 50 presidenti e primi ministri (tra cui William Clinton), 47 premi Nobel e un Papa.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La universidad de Oxford, Inglaterra, es la universidad más antigua del mundo angloparlante y también es una de las más prestigiosas. Se desconoce la fecha exacta de su fundación, aunque algunos estudiosos la sitúan alrededor del 1100.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oxford se compone de treinta y nueve colegios universitarios y siete "colegios mayores privados permanentes" (que son organizaciones religiosas). Cada uno está albergado en un edificio diferente, construido normalmente en un cuadrado alrededor de un cuadrilátero. Los colegios universitarios por lo general se componen de un salón, una capilla, una biblioteca, un bar, varias salas comunes, aulas y habitaciones para alrededor de trescientos estudiantes. Construidos a mediados del s. XIII, los colegios de Balliol y Merton y los de la propia universidad se cuentan entre los más antiguos.[PARAGRAPH:2]Durante gran parte de su existencia, Oxford ha sido una de las mejores universidades del mundo y sigue siéndolo en nuestros días. Muchos personajes famosos han pasado por sus estancias, incluyendo cuatro reyes ingleses y ocho extranjeros, más de cincuenta presidentes y primeros ministros (incluido William Clinton, presidente de los EE. UU.), cuarenta y siete ganadores de los premios Nobel y un papa.

TEXT.English: Heroic Epic

[TAB]As a literary genre of high culture, romance or chivalric romance is a style of heroic prose and verse narrative that was popular in the aristocratic circles of High Medieval and Early Modern Europe. They were fantastic stories about the marvelous adventures of a chivalrous, heroic knight errant, often of super-human ability, who often goes on a quest. Popular literature also drew on themes of romance, but with ironic, satiric or burlesque intent. Romances reworked legends, fairy tales, and history to suit tastes, but by c.1600 they were out of fashion and Miguel de Cervantes famously satirised them in his novel Don Quixote.[PARAGRAPH:2]Originally, romance literature was written in Old French, Anglo-Norman and Occitan, later, in English and German. During the early 13th century romances were increasingly written as prose. In later romances, particularly those of French origin, there is a marked tendency to emphasize themes of courtly love, such as faithfulness in adversity. From ca. 1800 the connotations of "romance" moved from the magical and fantastic to somewhat eerie "Gothic" adventure narratives.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Epos gehört zur Dichtung, ist im Unterschied zum jüngeren Roman aber nicht unbedingt Literatur, weil seine kulturelle Bedeutung den Umgang mit Texten und das Lesenkönnen nicht voraussetzt. Mit der mündlichen Verbreitung hängt die Versform des Epos zusammen, die als Gedankenstütze und Deklamationshilfe dient. Epen handeln von bedeutenden Ereignissen, bei denen oft Götter oder Helden im Mittelpunkt stehen (siehe Mythos). Antike und mittelalterliche Epen stammen nicht unbedingt von Autoren im modernen Sinne her, sind also keine individualistischen und eigenschöpferischen Werke. Im 18./19. Jahrhundert versuchte man sie auch als kollektive "Volksdichtungen" zu verstehen, was jedoch nicht zutrifft.

TEXT.English: National Gallery

[TAB]A national gallery is a country's major public art gallery. With different names, they are widespread in almost every nation capital. They are a space for the exhibition of art, usually visual art, and usually primarily paintings, illustrations, and sculpture. The art museum is considered a fairly modern invention, the first being the Louvre in Paris, which was established in 1793, soon after the French Revolution when the royal treasures were declared for the people.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une galerie nationale est la principale galerie d'art ouverte au public dans un pays. Bien que les appellations changent suivant les pays, on en trouve une dans presque chaque capitale du monde. Ces bâtiments servent à exposer les arts _ généralement visuels _ et notamment les peintures, les illustrations et les sculptures. On considère que le musée d'art est une invention assez moderne ; le plus ancien est le Louvre, qui ouvrit en 1793, peu après la Révolution française, lorsque les trésors royaux ont été déclarés propriété du peuple.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Nationalgalerie ist die größte öffentlich zugängliche Kunstgalerie eines Landes. Diese Galerien sind unter verschiedenen Bezeichnungen in fast allen Hauptstädten weit verbreitet und dienen als Ausstellungsorte für Kunst, meist bildende Kunst, und zwar in erster Linie für Gemälde, Illustrationen und Skulpturen. Das Kunstmuseum als solches ist eine relativ moderne Einrichtung: Die erste Institution dieser Art war der Pariser Louvre, der erst 1793 - kurz nach der französischen Revolution - gebaut wurde, nachdem die königlichen Schätze per Dekret dem Volk zugänglich gemacht worden waren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Una galleria nazionale è la principale galleria d'arte pubblica di una nazione. Con diversi nomi se ne trovano in quasi ogni capitale. Sono uno spazio per l'esibizione dell'arte, solitamente visiva, e principalmente dipinti, illustrazioni e sculture. Il museo d'arte è considerato un'invenzione abbastanza moderna: il primo è quello del Louvre a Parigi fondato nel 1793, poco dopo la rivoluzione francese, quando i tesori reali vennero dichiarati di proprietà del popolo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Una galería nacional es un gran museo de arte público de un país. Recibe diferentes nombres, pero casi todas las capitales del mundo cuentan con una de ellas. Hay un espacio para la exhibición de elementos artísticos, normalmente artes visuales, fundamentalmente pintura, ilustración y escultura. El museo de arte se considera una invención relativamente moderna. El primero de ellos fue el Louvre en París, fundado en 1793, al poco de finalizar la Revolución Francesa y tras declarar públicos los bienes de la realeza.

TEXT.English: National Theatre

[TAB]Most of the plays of William Shakespeare were first performed on the stage of London's Globe Theater during the 1600s. Theaters offered people a diversion from their everyday lives by allowing them to enjoy comedies, tragedies, and triumphs acted out on stage. Similar theaters, such as the Comedie Francaise in Paris, and La Scala in Milan, fulfilled similar roles by offering entertainment to the citizens of their cities. Although the original Globe Theater burned down, Shakespeare's plays are still performed in a new theater bearing his name, and in other theaters throughout the world.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La majorité des pièces de théâtre de William Shakespeare ont d'abord été jouées sur la scène du théâtre du Globe, à Londres, dans les années 1600. Les théâtres offraient au peuple la possibilité d'oublier son train-train quotidien en lui permettant d'assister à des comédies, des tragédies et des triomphes reconstitués sur scène. Des théâtres similaires tels que la Comédie Française à Paris et La Scala à Milan remplissaient le même rôle en offrant des divertissements aux citoyens de leur ville. Le théâtre du Globe d'origine a brûlé mais les pièces de Shakespeare continuent à être jouées dans un nouveau théâtre, portant le même nom, ainsi que dans d'autres théâtres du monde entier.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die meisten Shakespeare-Dramen wurden um 1600 auf der Bühne des Globe Theatre in London uraufgeführt. Das Theater bot der Bevölkerung die Gelegenheit, sich fern des Alltags zu amüsieren und an Komödien, Tragödien und Triumphen zu erfreuen, die auf der Schauspielbühne dargeboten wurden. Weitere Theater wie die Comédie Française in Paris und die Scala in Mailand boten den Bürgern der jeweiligen Städte ebenfalls Unterhaltung und Zerstreuung. Das ursprüngliche Globe Theatre brannte zwar nieder, aber auch heute noch werden die Dramen von Shakespeare in einem neuen Theater gleichen Namens sowie in zahlreichen anderen Theaterhäusern in aller Welt aufgeführt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La maggior parte delle opere teatrali di William Shakespeare andarono in scena per la prima volta al Globe Theatre di Londra. Il teatro offriva alla gente un diversivo alle tribolazioni della vita quotidiana, consentendo di assistere a commedie, tragedie e successi rappresentati sul palcoscenico. Teatri simili, come la Comedie Française a Parigi, o La Scala a Milano, svolgevano un ruolo dello stesso genere, attirando con le loro rappresentazioni spettatori da tutte le aree circostanti. Nonostante il Globe Theatre sia ormai da tempo andato distrutto in un incendio, le opere di Shakespeare vengono tutt'oggi rappresentate in un nuovo teatro che porta il suo nome e in quelli di tutto il mondo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La mayoría de las obras de William Shakespeare fueron representadas por vez primera en el escenario del Globe Theatre de Londres durante el siglo XVII. Los teatros ofrecían a la gente entretenimiento en su rutina diaria, pues les permitían disfrutar de las comedias, tragedias y triunfos representados en escena. Otros teatros similares, como la Comédie Française de París y La Scala de Milán, desempeñaban papeles similares ofreciendo diversión a los habitantes de sus ciudades. Aunque el Globe Theatre original se incendió, las obras de Shakespeare aún se representan en un nuevo teatro bautizado con su nombre, y en otros teatros de todo el mundo.

TEXT.English: Royal Dungeon

[TAB]The most famous Royal Dungeon is located in England. Her Majesty's Royal Palace and Fortress, more commonly known as the Tower of London (and historically as The Tower), is a historic fortress and scheduled monument in central London, on the north bank of the River Thames. It is located within the London Borough of Tower Hamlets and is separated from the eastern edge of the City of London by the open space known as Tower Hill. It is the oldest building used by the British government.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Tower of London is often identified with the White Tower, the original stark square fortress built by William the Conqueror in 1078. However, the tower as a whole is a complex of several buildings set within two concentric rings of defensive walls and a moat.[PARAGRAPH:2]The tower's primary function was a fortress, a royal palace, and a prison (particularly for high status and royal prisoners, such as the Princes in the Tower and the future Queen Elizabeth I). This last use has led to the phrase "sent to the Tower" (meaning "imprisoned"). It has also served as a place of execution and torture, an armoury, a treasury, a zoo, the Royal Mint, a public records office, an observatory, and since 1303, the home of the Crown Jewels of the United Kingdom.

Er diente den englischen und britischen Königen unter anderem als Burg, Waffenkammer (stronghouse), königlicher Palast und Gefängnis.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ursprünglich wurde der Tower als Festung Wilhelm des Eroberers gegen die potentiell feindseligen Bürger der Stadt London errichtet. Bis zu Jakob I. nutzen alle englischen Könige und Königinnen den Tower zeitweilig zum Aufenthalt. Es war üblich, dass der Monarch vor dem Tag seiner Krönung im Tower übernachtete und dann in feierlichem Zug durch die Stadt nach Westminster ritt. Als Stützpunkt der britischen Monarchie im historischen Zentrum Londons ist der Tower eng mit der britischen Geschichte verbunden.

TEXT.English: Royal Academy

[TAB]In Florence, the Medici established the Accademia di Belle Arti Firenze in 1563, the first of the more formally organised art academies that gradually displaced the medieval artists' guilds, usually known as the Guild of Saint Luke, as the bodies responsible for training and often regulating artists, a change with great implications for the development of art, leading to the styles known as Academic art. The private academy set up later in the century in Bologna by the Carracci brothers was also extremely influential, and with the Accademia di San Luca of Rome (founded 1593) helped to confirm the use of the term for these institutions.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Académie de peinture et de sculpture in Paris, established by the monarchy in 1648 (later renamed) was the most significant of the artistic academies, running the famous Salon exhibitions from 1725. Artistic academies were established all over Europe by the end of the 18th century, and many, like the Royal Academy in London (founded 1768) still run art schools and hold large exhibitions, although their influence on taste greatly declined from the late 19th century.[PARAGRAPH:2]A fundamental feature of academic discipline in the artistic academies was regular practice in making accurate drawings from antiquities, or from casts of antiquities, on the one hand, and on the other, in deriving inspiration from the other fount, the human form. Students assembled in sessions drawing the draped and undraped human form, and such drawings, which survive in the tens of thousands from the 17th through the 19th century, are termed académies in French.[PARAGRAPH:2]Similar institutions were often established for other arts; Paris had the Académie Royale de Musique from 1669, and the Académie d'architecture from 1671.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Royal Academy of Arts wurde 1768 von 40 Künstlern unter Leitung von Joshua Reynolds gegründet. Auslöser war ein Streit innerhalb der damals führenden Künstlervereinigung Society of Artists. Der Architekt William Chambers verließ diese Vereinigung, nachdem er vergeblich für die Präsidentschaft kandidiert hatte. Nachdem er seine guten Verbindungen zum englischen Königshaus genutzt hatte, bewilligte Georg III. schließlich die Gründung einer neuen Künstlervereinigung. Sie nahm ihre Arbeit offiziell im Folgejahr 1769 auf. Die Akademie nimmt maximal 80 Mitglieder auf.

TEXT.English: National Epic

[TAB]An "epic" is a heroic poem celebrating the life and achievements of a heroic individual or group. Classic examples of epics include Homer's "Iliad" and "Odyssey."[PARAGRAPH:2]A "national epic" celebrates the exploits of an entire country. One of the earliest examples is the "Shahnama," (The Book of Kings), a Persian literary classic written around 1000 AD. The Shahnama chronicles the history of Persia from mythological pre-history through the reign of Khosrau II (590-628). The work contains over 60,000 couplets and is still read and enjoyed by modern readers.[PARAGRAPH:2]It is possible that the age of the literary epic is dead, and that in the future all such stories will be done as "made for TV movies." This would be a great misfortune to the world of letters - and to the rest of the world, as well.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une "épopée" est un poème épique célébrant la vie et les exploits d'un héros ou d'un groupe héroïque. Les exemples classiques d'épopées sont "l'Iliade" et "l'Odyssée" d'Homère.[PARAGRAPH:2]Une "épopée nationale" célèbre les exploits de tout un pays. L'un des plus anciens exemples est le "Chah-namè" (Le livre des rois), un chef-d'oeuvre de la littérature perse écrit vers 1000 ap. J.-C. Le Chah-namè relate l'histoire de la Perse de la Préhistoire mythologique jusqu'au règne de Khosrô II Abharvêzou (590-628). L'oeuvre comporte plus de 60 000 distiques et est toujours lue et appréciée par les lecteurs contemporains.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il est possible que l'âge des oeuvres épiques soit révolu et qu'à l'avenir, de telles histoires soient écrites en vue d'être "adaptées en téléfilms". Ce serait un grand malheur pour le monde des lettres, et le reste du monde également.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein "Epos" beschreibt die Taten und Leistungen eines oder mehrerer Helden. Klassische Epen sind beispielsweise Homers "Ilias" und die "Odyssee."[PARAGRAPH:2]Ein "Nationalepos" feiert die Heldentaten eines ganzen Landes. Eines der ersten Nationalepen war das "Shahnama" (Das Buch der Könige), ein um 1000 verfasster Klassiker der persischen Literatur. Das Shahnama zeichnet die Geschichte Persiens von der mythologischen Frühgeschichte bis zur Regentschaft Khosraus II. (590-628) auf. Es besteht aus über 60.000 Reimpaaren und ist auch heute noch lesbar und unterhaltsam.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die Zeit literarischer Epen mag zwar vergangen sein, seit das Zeitalter des Films eingesetzt hat. Allerdings wäre der Untergang des Epos nicht nur für die Wissenschaft ein schwerer Verlust.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un "poema epico" è una saga che celebra la vita e le vittorie di individui o gruppi. I classici esempi sono l'Iliade e l'Odissea di Omero.[PARAGRAPH:2]Un "poema epico nazionale" celebra le gesta di un intero paese. Uno degli esempi più antichi è lo "Shahnama," (il libro dei re), un classico della letteratura Persiana scritto intorno al 1000 d. C. Lo Shahnama è il resoconto della storia di Persia dalla preistoria fino al regno di Khosrau II (590-628). Il lavoro è composto da più di 60.000 strofe ed è una lettura godibile anche oggi.[PARAGRAPH:2]Probabilmente l'epoca della letteratura epica è terminata e nel futuro tutte le grandi storie verranno narrate in "film per la TV".
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un "ciclo épico" es un poema heroico que celebra la vida y los logros de un individuo o un grupo. Entre los ejemplos clásicos de ciclos épicos se encuentran la Ilíada y la Odisea de Homero.[PARAGRAPH:2]Un "ciclo épico nacional" celebra los logros de un país entero. Uno de los primeros ejemplos es el "Shahnama," (el Libro de los Reyes), un clásico de la literatura persa que data aproximadamente del año 1000 a. C. El Shahnama relata la historia de Persia, desde los tiempos mitológicos prehistóricos hasta el reinado de Cosroes II (590-628). La obra contiene más de 60.000 pareados y aún sigue siendo objeto de disfrute y estudio por parte de lectores de nuestro tiempo.[PARAGRAPH:2]Es posible que la edad de los poemas épicos haya pasado, y que en el futuro todas las historias se compongan como los guiones de televisión. Ésta sería una gran tragedia para el mundo de las letras... y para el resto del mundo.

TEXT.English: Triumphal Arch

[TAB]A triumphal arch is a structure in the shape of a monumental archway, usually built to celebrate a victory in war. The arch is invariably a free-standing structure, quite separate from city gates or walls. In its simplest form a triumphal arch consists of two pillars connected by an arch, crowned with a superstructure or attic on which a statue or commemorative inscriptions might be mounted. More elaborate triumphal arches have flanking subsidiary archways, typically a pair. Famous arches include the Arch of Titus in Rome and the Arc de Triomphe in Paris.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un arc de triomphe est un ouvrage en forme d'arche monumentale, généralement construit pour célébrer une victoire à la guerre. L'arc est toujours une structure indépendante, à l'écart des portes et des remparts de la ville. Dans sa forme la plus simple, l'arc de triomphe se compose de deux piliers reliés par un arc et surmontés d'un entablement ou d'un attique sur lequel peuvent être ajoutées une statue ou des inscriptions commémoratives. Les arcs de triomphe plus élaborés comportent des arches secondaires - généralement au nombre de deux - sur les côtés. Parmi les arcs de triomphes les plus célèbres, on trouve l'Arc de Titus à Rome et l'Arc de triomphe de l'Etoile à Paris.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Triumphbogen ist ein frei stehendes Bauwerk in Form eines monumentalen Tors oder Bogengangs, das üblicherweise zur Würdigung eines bedeutenden militärischen Sieges abseits von Stadttoren oder -mauern errichtet wird. In seiner einfachsten Form besteht ein Triumphbogen aus zwei Säulen, die durch einen Bogen verbunden und mit einer Attika versehen sind, auf der eine Statue thront oder eine Inschrift angebracht ist. Aufwändiger gearbeitete Triumphbögen haben zusätzlich noch angrenzende Seitenbogengänge, die meist paarweise angeordnet sind. Berühmte Triumphbögen sind beispielsweise der Titusbogen in Rom und der Arc de Triomphe in Paris.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un arco di trionfo è una struttura con la forma di una monumentale arcata, spesso costruita per celebrare la vittoria in una guerra. L'arco è invariabilmente una struttura a sé stante, separata dalle mura o dalle porte di una città. Nella sua forma più semplice un arco di trionfo consiste di due colonne unite da un arco, sovrastato da una struttura o un attico su cui si possono trovare statue o iscrizioni. Gli archi di trionfo più elaborati possono avere arcate sussidiarie laterali, di solito una coppia. Tra i più famosi sono l'Arco di Tito a Roma e l'Arco di Trionfo a Parigi.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un Arco de Triunfo es una enorme arcada monumental que se suele construir para celebrar una victoria en la guerra. El arco siempre es una estructura solitaria, separada de las puertas o muros de la ciudad. En su forma más sencilla consiste en dos pilares conectados por un arco que a su vez está coronado por una estructura superior en la cual se suele colocar una estatua o una inscripción conmemorativa. Los Arcos de Triunfo más elaborados pueden tener un par de arcos secundarios en los laterales. Los más famosos son el Arco de Tito en Roma y el Arco del Triunfo de Paris.
